misconceptions.name: Implemented distance calculator instead of grade calculator
misconceptions.description: The student wrote a program to compute the distance between two points, rather than reading a single numeric grade and mapping it to a letter grade as specified in the problem.
misconceptions.student_belief: The student appears to believe the task is to read coordinates (x1, y1, x2, y2) and compute the distance between two points, or reused code for that problem for this question.
misconceptions.correct_understanding: For this question, the program should read one numeric grade between 0 and 100 and use conditional statements to determine and print the corresponding letter grade (A, B, C, D, or F) based on the given ranges.
symptoms: Program prompts for point coordinates instead of a single grade.
No conditional logic testing grade ranges such as 90–100, 80–89, etc.
Output reports a distance value, not a letter grade.
misconceptions.root_cause: Misinterpretation of the problem requirements or mixing up this question with a different assignment about distances between points.
misconceptions.remediation_hint: Re-read the problem statement carefully and restate it in your own words before coding. Identify the exact input (one grade value), the decision logic (if/else-if for each grade range), and the required output format (letter grade). Then design and implement your code to match those requirements.
misconceptions.confidence_rationale: The entire program is structured around distance computation with no elements related to grade ranges or letter output, indicating a clear mismatch with the assignment.

evidence.note: All input, computation, and output are about point coordinates and distance, not about reading a single grade and mapping it to a letter grade.

misconceptions.name: Misinterpreted Problem Requirements (Wrong Assignment)
misconceptions.description: The student submitted a complete program for calculating the distance between two points, failing to implement any of the required logic for the Grade Calculator task (reading a single grade and using conditional statements to map it to a letter grade).
misconceptions.student_belief: The student likely submitted the incorrect file for this question, or misunderstood the scope of the assignment.
misconceptions.correct_understanding: The assignment required reading a single integer grade (0-100) and using if-else if-else statements to determine the corresponding letter grade (A, B, C, D, F).
symptoms: Code reads four floating-point inputs (x1, y1, x2, y2)
Code performs geometric calculation (distance formula)
Output is 'The distance of the two points is [number]', not 'Letter grade: [letter]'
misconceptions.root_cause: The student solved the wrong problem or submitted the wrong file.
misconceptions.remediation_hint: Please review the assignment prompt for Question 3 and submit the program that implements the Grade Calculator functionality, including input reading and conditional grading logic.
misconceptions.confidence_rationale: The submitted code is entirely functional but addresses a different, recognizable problem (Distance Calculator), confirming a complete misinterpretation or file submission error.

evidence.note: The entire program implements a calculation for distance between two points (Q2, or similar), not a grade calculator (Q3).

misconceptions.name: Wrong Problem Implementation
misconceptions.description: The student implemented a completely different program (distance between points calculator) instead of the assigned grade calculator program.
misconceptions.student_belief: The student appears to believe they should solve a distance calculation problem rather than a grade classification problem.
misconceptions.correct_understanding: The assignment requires reading a numeric grade (0-100) and outputting the corresponding letter grade (A/B/C/D/F) based on the specified ranges. This is a conditional logic problem, not a coordinate geometry problem.
symptoms: Program reads x and y coordinates instead of a grade
Program calculates distance instead of determining letter grade
Output shows distance value instead of letter grade
No grade ranges or conditionals present
misconceptions.root_cause: Complete misunderstanding or misreading of the assignment requirements. The student may have submitted code from a different problem or solved the wrong question entirely.
misconceptions.remediation_hint: Re-read the assignment carefully. Write a program that: (1) reads a single numeric grade, (2) uses if-else statements to check grade ranges, (3) outputs the corresponding letter grade A/B/C/D/F based on the scale provided.
misconceptions.confidence_rationale: Absolute certainty - the submitted code solves a completely different problem (distance calculation) than what was assigned (grade classification). The code structure, logic, and output are entirely inconsistent with the assignment requirements.

evidence.note: The entire program implements distance calculation between two points, not grade classification. This is a completely different problem from the assignment.
Program prompts for coordinates instead of a single numeric grade. Assignment requires: 'Enter grade: '

evidence.snippet: System.out.println("The distance of the two points is " + distance);
evidence.note: Program outputs a distance value instead of a letter grade. No conditional logic to determine A/B/C/D/F grades.

misconceptions.name: Implemented distance-between-points program instead of grade calculator
misconceptions.description: The student wrote a complete program to compute the distance between two points in 2D space instead of the requested grade-to-letter-grade calculator. The program never reads a single numeric grade in the 0–100 range or maps it to A/B/C/D/F using conditional logic.
misconceptions.student_belief: I need to write a program that reads coordinates for two points (x1, y1) and (x2, y2) and prints the distance between them using the distance formula.
misconceptions.correct_understanding: The task is to write a grade calculator: read one numeric grade between 0 and 100 from the keyboard, then use conditionals to determine and print the corresponding letter grade (A, B, C, D, or F) based on the specified ranges.
symptoms: Program prompts for x1, y1, x2, y2 instead of a single grade value.
All variables relate to coordinates and differences (x1, y1, x2, y2, dx, dy, distance).
No conditional statements checking grade ranges (90–100, 80–89, etc.).
Output message reports distance between two points, not a letter grade.
misconceptions.root_cause: The student likely misread or confused the assignment prompt and implemented a different, previously seen problem (distance between two points) instead of the grade calculator.
misconceptions.remediation_hint: Re-read the problem statement carefully and ensure each input, variable, and output directly corresponds to the described grade calculator behavior. Start by reading a single numeric grade, then add an if/else-if/else chain to handle the A/B/C/D/F ranges, and finally print the correct letter grade.
related_concepts: Mapping problem requirements to code structure
misconceptions.confidence_rationale: The entire program is devoted to computing distance between two points, with no mention of grades, letter grades, or conditional logic, which strongly indicates the problem was misunderstood.

evidence.note: All input, computation, and output relate to distance between points, with no grade input or letter grade output as required by the grade calculator problem.

misconceptions.name: Failure to address the assigned problem
misconceptions.description: The student implemented a solution for a different problem (calculating the distance between two points) instead of the required Grade Calculator problem (Q3).
misconceptions.student_belief: The student likely submitted an implementation for a previous or unrelated assignment (Distance between Points) instead of the required Grade Calculator (Q3).
misconceptions.correct_understanding: The student must write code that specifically addresses the prompt for Q3: reading a single numeric grade and outputting the corresponding letter grade using conditional logic.
symptoms: Code calculates distance between points
Code reads four double inputs (x1, y1, x2, y2) instead of one integer input (grade)
Conditional logic for grading is completely absent
misconceptions.root_cause: Misinterpretation of the assignment requirements or accidental submission of the wrong file/code block.
misconceptions.remediation_hint: Please review the assignment prompt for Q3 ('Grade Calculator') and ensure the submitted code addresses that specific requirement.
misconceptions.confidence_rationale: The supplied code (DistanceBetweenPoints.java) directly solves an unrelated geometry problem, making it a complete failure to meet the requirements of the requested 'Grade Calculator' assignment (Q3).

evidence.note: The entire code implements the distance formula, which is entirely irrelevant to the Grade Calculator problem Q3.

misconceptions.name: Complete Problem Misinterpretation
misconceptions.description: The student appears to have misunderstood the assignment entirely and submitted a solution to a completely different problem (distance between two points). The submission does not address any aspect of the grade calculator requirements.
misconceptions.student_belief: The student appears to believe they are solving a distance calculation problem between two coordinate points.
misconceptions.correct_understanding: The assignment requires a grade calculator that reads a single numeric grade (0-100) and outputs the corresponding letter grade (A, B, C, D, or F) based on the specified ranges.
symptoms: Program reads four coordinate values instead of one grade
Program calculates Euclidean distance instead of determining letter grade
No conditional logic for grade ranges (90-100, 80-89, 70-79, 60-69, <60)
Class name is 'DistanceBetweenPoints' instead of related to grade calculation
Output format completely wrong (distance value vs. letter grade)
misconceptions.root_cause: Student either submitted the wrong file by mistake, did not read the assignment specification carefully, or misunderstood what Q3 was asking for.
misconceptions.remediation_hint: 1) Re-read the Q3 assignment carefully. 2) Start fresh: create a new program that reads ONE grade input (0-100). 3) Use if-else statements to check grade ranges in order (A, B, C, D, F). 4) Output only the letter grade.
misconceptions.confidence_rationale: The submission contains zero elements of the required grade calculator. It is a complete solution to a different problem (distance calculation). This is definitive evidence of problem misinterpretation.

evidence.note: Program is reading 4 coordinate values instead of 1 numeric grade (0-100)

evidence.snippet:
double distance = Math.sqrt(dx * dx + dy * dy);
        System.out.println("The distance of the two points is " + distance);
evidence.note: Program calculates distance formula instead of implementing grade-to-letter conversion logic with if-else ranges
Class name is 'DistanceBetweenPoints', indicating student coded a different problem than Q3 Grade Calculator
